clinical_study.brief_title: Study of Cortisol Metabolism in Familial Partial Lipodystrophy Type 2
clinical_study.official_title: Study of Cortisol Metabolism in Familial Partial Lipodystrophy Type 2

brief_summary.textblock: Familial partial lipodystrophic syndromes are characterized by an increase in visceral adipose tissue and an atrophy of subcutaneous adipose tissue. They are associated with a severe metabolic syndrome especially when linked to the mutation of the R482 codon of the LMNA gene (Familial partial lipodystrophy type 2, FPL2). Data in lipodystrophy induced by antiretroviral therapy of HIV suggests an increase in the activity of 11β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase type 1 (11bHSD1). This enzyme reactivates cortisone in cortisol in adipose tissues and liver and has associated to obesity and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Hence, the hypothesis is that in patients suffering from FPL2 with the R482 codon mutation of the LMNA gene, there is an increase in the activity of HSD11B1 which could participate to the metabolic phenotype of the disease.

primary_outcome.measure: THE/(THF+αTHF) ratio measured in the 24h urine collections in patients

secondary_outcome.measure: 11BHSD1 expression in subcutaneous adipose tissue in patients
Correlation of 11BHSD1 activity and metabolic parameters in patients

arm_group.description: patients suffering with FPL2 with the R482 codon mutation of the LMNA gene.

biospec_descr.textblock: A 24 hours urine collection; Biopsy of subcutaneous adipose tissue

study_pop.textblock: Patients suffering from FPL2 with the R482 codon mutation of the LMNA gene treated in the department of endocrinology at Lille University Hospital.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Familia partial lipodystrophy type 2 (FPL2) with the R482 codon mutation of the LMNA gene
- Social insured
- Ability to give consent
Exclusion Criteria:
- urinary incontinence or inability to collect urine for 24 hours
- moderate and severe kidney insufficiency
- hepatic insufficiency
- history of hypercortisolism or adrenal insufficiency
- treatment interfering with the cortisol metabolism: taking oral or inhaled glucocorticoids within the last 6 months
- pregnant and lactating woman.
